body:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d6Z8etbe6Xs (I suggest viewing in Cinema mode)

Video Description:
This video consists of basic editing skills demonstrated in the world of minecraft in a server known as Avicus. I really enjoy playing this server and I thought I'd share it with you. (Also I would've uploaded the more quality video, but it was to high, xD)


Also, I'm on the hunt for some constructive feedback of these basic editing skills, hopefully you enjoyed!

replies.body:
I'll just put these suggestions as points:

- If you're going to record and use slow motion, you should seriously consider recording at a higher frame rate (60fps+)

- I'm not sure if you can record Minecraft in 1080p but if so, this would also improve the quality.

- When you're looking around there seems to be a choppy feel. If it's possible to make the movement smooth it will also improve the quality. Otherwise the mouse shouldn't be moved.

- Incorporate some actual gameplay with the video.

replies.body:
1st: (I was with 60fps)

2nd. The quality Originally was higher however youtube couldn't take it. I had the highest quality possible with my video editor but unfortunately youtube just increased the time to infinity

3rd: Yeah, I am going to improve that.

4th: I'll consider, it's just more laggy when I record :P

Just random piece of information:
It was originally 20 minutes xD

replies.body: Fairly certain it was 30fps, Youtube even sees it as 30. I'm not sure what you mean by "Youtube couldn't take it," as Youtube can take 1080p videos, there are videos on youtube that are 8k. I'm assuming uploading 1080p takes a while on your internet so either go somewhere where there's faster internet or leave it uploading overnight.

replies.body:
I enjoyed it! I'm not familiar with Movavi. It didn't seem choppy or blurry for me at all.  I could view in 720p and it was fine.  Did you use the Movavi Video Editor to edit or something else?

Here are some suggestions:
  • Coordinate the action a bit more with the music
  • Make the video cuts closer together like one every 4-8 seconds (to the beat of the music)
  • Add "Hollywood-worthy" effects https://www.movavi.com/ (What exactly are those? lol)
Looking forward to more videos! :)
